pullrequest.title: OPW Path planner: I model move plugin/example
OPW Path planner: I model move plugin/example

content.raw:
hmmm, I'm a bit confused about `path` right now. This initialization list allocates an empty `math::Vector3` object to path, but in `Load` it gets allocated with the number of points specified in SDF. I would think to be consistent that an "empty" path would be a NULL pointer, not a pointer to a `math::Vector3` object.

Maybe `path` should be a `std::vector` instead of a pointer, and it could get allocated with the number of points from SDF using `std::vector::capacity`? It's a more C++ way of doing things.
content.html:
hmmm, I'm a bit confused about path right now. This initialization list allocates an empty math::Vector3 object to path, but in Load it gets allocated with the number of points specified in SDF. I would think to be consistent that an "empty" path would be a NULL pointer, not a pointer to a math::Vector3 object.

Maybe path should be a std::vector instead of a pointer, and it could get allocated with the number of points from SDF using std::vector::capacity? It's a more C++ way of doing things.

content.raw: From the documentation in the beginning, it sounds like we should read 6 floats from the "path" SDF block at a time and store those 6 floats as a `Pose`. But here, it looks like we read 3 floats at a time and store them as a `Vector3`. (I haven't run the code yet, so I don't yet know if this behaves as expected, but it seems strange.)
content.html: From the documentation in the beginning, it sounds like we should read 6 floats from the "path" SDF block at a time and store those 6 floats as a Pose. But here, it looks like we read 3 floats at a time and store them as a Vector3. (I haven't run the code yet, so I don't yet know if this behaves as expected, but it seems strange.)

pullrequest.title: OPW Path planner: I model move plugin/example

content.raw: If I call the `path_publisher` once, then call it again before the path is finished, it teleports the box back to the starting point. I would have thought that it would either append the waypoints, so that it does the path twice, or overwrites the current waypoints, so that it drives to the first point from wherever it happened to be when it received the message.
content.html: If I call the path_publisher once, then call it again before the path is finished, it teleports the box back to the starting point. I would have thought that it would either append the waypoints, so that it does the path twice, or overwrites the current waypoints, so that it drives to the first point from wherever it happened to be when it received the message.

pullrequest.title: OPW Path planner: I model move plugin/example

OPW Path planner: I model move plugin/example
OPW Path planner: I model move plugin/example

content.raw:
This suggestion will require you to change the implementation slightly, but it is cleaner XML. Instead of specifying mulitple poses in the `<path>` element, use multiple `<pose>` elements. For example:


```
#!xml

<plugin name="model_move" filename="libmodel_move.so">
    <pose>5 5 0 0 0 0</pose>
    <pose>5 -5 0 0 0 0</pose>
    <pose>0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
</plugin>
```

This will allow you to ditch `<n_points>`, use Gazebo's built in `<pose>` handling, and is a bit more readable.
content.html:
This suggestion will require you to change the implementation slightly, but it is cleaner XML. Instead of specifying mulitple poses in the <path> element, use multiple <pose> elements. For example:

<plugin name="model_move" filename="libmodel_move.so">
    <pose>5 5 0 0 0 0</pose>
    <pose>5 -5 0 0 0 0</pose>
    <pose>0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
</plugin>

This will allow you to ditch <n_points>, use Gazebo's built in <pose> handling, and is a bit more readable.

pullrequest.title: OPW Path planner: I model move plugin/example

content.raw:
That is a really good idea. I just add a <goals> tag which I believe make things easier to read and leave the things cleaner to add some new parameters in the future. 


```
#!xml
<plugin name="model_move" filename="libmodel_move.so">
  <goals>
     <pose>5 5 0 0 0 0</pose>
     <pose>5 -5 0 0 0 0</pose>
     <pose>0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
  </goals>
</plugin>
```

[Commit](https://bitbucket.org/rahwang/gazebo-opw14-path-planner/commits/21d4f2d6c3b9384d33b1e9cf993bce3db46db3a1) in Rachel's repo.
content.html:
That is a really good idea. I just add a <goals> tag which I believe make things easier to read and leave the things cleaner to add some new parameters in the future. 

<plugin name="model_move" filename="libmodel_move.so">
  <goals>
     <pose>5 5 0 0 0 0</pose>
     <pose>5 -5 0 0 0 0</pose>
     <pose>0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
  </goals>
</plugin>

Commit in Rachel's repo.
